title: What will be the closing price for Brent crude oil on 31 March 2020?
preds: Current price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia will put downward pressure on all oil producers. Unlikely there will be a 300% increase in price over 1 day.
Will not recover from current oversupply
There is no chance of a rapid recovery from current price of $27 to  $63 or above in the next six days.
Price is well below $63.00 right now, at around $30 today, prices are dropping quicker than they did in 2001 and 2008.
Our long-standing forecast has been less than $30/bbl as OPEC has lost control of the market (again)
Current price about $45, epidemic in full swing! Demand crushed.
Price has not been above $63 for one month.  Currently under $30.

Price has radically dropped due to a plethora of reasons. Two big ones is that obviously the coronavirus is definitely damaging both supply lines and demand for oil. The insistence by large entities on staying home will lead to a huge drop in demand for oil. Furthermore, the recent oil price war between russia and saudi arabia means that there is a huge amount of oil on the market thus increasing the supply in order to incentivise people to drive their cars and go out.  I added a 1% chance because you never know.
It is down to 25 cannot see it picking up anytime soon
Based on current prices and events

I sucked at this challenge - bad first prediction made worse by being slow to respond. 
Shame on me. :(

This is a no brainer now.  Isn't it funny how times have changed?  Its times like these I wish I could give 99.9% chance but things still can happen and if Saudi Arabia and or Russia is taken down by the coronavirus markets can react quickly.

Updating to reflect the historic price plunge in Oil over the past week. A price above $63 by end March would represent a historic rise highly unlikely to happen given Coronavirus/ramping up of another price war
recent events have over whelmed this question. We will be lucky to see $40 per barrel based on today
Russia and Saudi Arabia dec8de to have a price war as epidemic spreads.
Saudi v Russia. No chance now.

Brent Crude is currently at just over $35 a barrel. News today that OPEC+ could not reach an agreement on production cuts and that Saudi Arabia and Russia both pledged to increase production has caused prices to crash. Both countries claim they can win the oil price war on the horizon. Additionally, COVID-19 is spreading rapidly throughout the world including Italy, South Korea, and the USA. The virus shows no signs of slowing, especially before March 31st. In the last five years, Brent Crude has been above $63 a barrel for only 9/60 months and only once on March 31st.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil/oil-prices-plunge-hit-by-erupting-saudi-russia-oil-price-war-idUSKBN20V131
https://www.macrotrends.net/1369/crude-oil-price-history-chart
https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CO1:COM
https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/summary.html
If the coronovirus situation peaks in the next week oil prices could spring back dramatically but it is unlikely that the price will go above $63 before the end of the month.
Way less with OPEC dischord and Russia making noise and will stay low.
After OPEC collapse this weekend adjusting probabilities.
Key oil producing nations apparently not in agreement about production levels: https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/08/opec-deal-collapse-sparks-price-war-20-oil-in-2020-is-coming.html

Saudi Arabia has started a price war after Russia refused OPECs plan to cut production in response to corona virus outbreak. The Saudi's reduced the cost of the crude oil they sell to foreign markets by the most in 20 years. As reported by Bloomberg, it is a shock and awe strategy, an effort to bring Russia back to the negotiating table. Prices are being slashed by $6-8 per barrel. Brent crude latest price is $45.50

The current price of Brent Oil as of 7 March 2020 is $53 dollars per barrel.  Oil was last above $63 in early January based on the likelihood of reduced trade disputes between the US and China lifting global growth. The current depressed price reflects the growing global pandemic (COVID-19).  May options (CME) are settling below $50 with only outliers showing a price of $63 (so if it does rebound quickly that is a big payout to whoever bought those call options).  Between reduced travel hitting jet fuel demands to reduced travel hitting gas prices, oil will continue to stay low until fears of the pandemic subside or OPEC gets involved.  Even if OPEC cuts production further it is unlikely to produce a 18.89% price change within three weeks. Let's update this forecast even more given data and a 8 Mar 20 price of 45.47.  The average monthly change in brent since 1990 is .6% and the standard deviation is 8.5%.  For oil to move beyond the first standard deviation would require a a move of 17.73% (well beyond the first standard deviation of monthly percent chg). Further the recent failure of OPEC to agree to any price cut further lowers the likelihood of going above $63.  In fact, even the recent Iranian attack on Saudi producton facilities didn't result in an oil spike that large.
Brent crude is down about 30 per cent since January.
Reaffirming forecast based on current market price.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil/oil-rises-as-opec-backs-deeper-supply-cuts-idUSKBN20S05T If it is sustained, this move will probably slow the decline and maybe even stabilize the price, but it's not going to bump prices up fifteen bucks in a couple of weeks.   On top of oil's other problems, The Virus has become a significant demandophage, which is not a word but should be.
nearing the date, reducing likelihood of other alternatives and factoring in lower present value. Previous reasons listed + coronavirus demand impact.

"Oil traders warn of ‘zero growth’ in 2020 demand due to coronavirus" - https://www.ft.com/content/ce954624-5ed2-11ea-b0ab-339c2307bcd4 - only a serious cut in production will raise prices, but will take time to filter through. Will revise after Russia/OPEC meetings.

The Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies meet today in Vienna. In December, they announced production cuts of 1.7m barrels a day, to brace themselves for booming production in not just America, a perpetual headache, but Brazil, Guyana and Norway. Those cuts now look woefully insufficient. The spread of covid-19 pushed the price of Brent crude below $50 a barrel during the course of the day on February 28th. Saudi Arabia is among the OPEC producers keen to raise prices quickly—the IMF estimates that the kingdom needs oil at $83.60 to balance its budget. Russia, which has allied itself with the cartel since 2016, has habitually opposed output cuts, only to agree to them at the last moment. To date the benefits of increased influence and business dealings with OPEC members have trumped complaints about production limits from Russia’s oil companies. Saudi Arabia is among those hoping that logic still holds in Vienna.
—————-
COMMENT: Time to go low!
No economic indicators that would point to a sudden surge in prices.

The Energy Information Agency (EIA) has estimated that the price of Brent crude oil will average $58 per barrel in the first half of 2020 before rising to an average of $64 per barrel in the final 6 months of 2020.  The EIA has made this forecast based on the expectation that inventories (i.e. supply) of oil increased in 2020 and will decrease in 2021.  The EIA’s forecast does not include any disruptions to oil supply (which would most likely increase the price of Brent crude oil).   Due to the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, investors are “panicking” and the markets (stock exchanges et al.) have gone down.  Since oil is fundamental to markets, its price (including that of Brent crude) has decreased. OPEC will be holding its meeting on March 5-6, 2020 to determine if they will extend the current production cuts of 1.7 million barrels per day that they agreed would run from December 2019 until the end of March 2020.  It is expected that OPEC will extend their production cuts.  Even if production cuts are extended, for now, the supply of oil is greater than the current demand.  The price of Brent crude may increase once OPEC’s decision is made public.  However, the price increase may be negligible and/or temporary given the EIA’s forecast. For now, I am confident that the closing price of Brent crude oil will be below $63 by the end of the day March 31, 2020. Sources:
https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/ https://www.eia.gov/finance/markets/crudeoil/index.php https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=42535 https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/marketreview/crude.php https://www.aljazeera.com/ajimpact/opec-meeting-russia-cagey-oil-cuts-200302141913065.html
Coronavirus will slow demand a lot

Russia and Opec are meeting this week, March 5-6, to discuss production cuts. Demand has taken a hit with coronavirus spread. Russia is said to be unsure on agreeing to more cuts. Price today is $53.06.  https://www.aljazeera.com/ajimpact/opec-meeting-russia-cagey-oil-cuts-200302141913065.html

Current price is $51.93.
Cannot see Covid doing anything other than press down on global demand to end March.
OPEC will try and manage that but can’t see them doing enough to get back to $63.
Passage of time and Covid-19 impact

Update: The Corona virus has disrupted the global supply chain so much that the OECD estimates that global growth could be halved in 2020. People and goods simply aren't moving which places significant strain on the oil industry. NASDAQ currently states the price to be $50, making it almost impossible with the current virus outbreak for the price to recover to the $60-$69 range

demand for crude oil will decline as government and self imposed travel restrictions continue to reduce demand for oil. March is now likely to roll out a stream of negative news linked to Corni-virus.

On the demand side,  Most oil is used for transport, and most of that for passenger transport. https://www.iea.org/data-and-statistics?country=WORLD&fuel=Oil&indicator=Oil%20products%20final%20consumption%20by%20sector  How cheap does travel have to be to encourage people to risk health?  Spring in the northern hemisphere so heating and A/C demand is low.    But the fall in the oil price is the mainly result of a supply shock. A production cut won't affect this.  And, an OPEC cut is already expected and priced in.  It would have to be enormous to push price back over $63.
Reaffirming with passage of time and impacts of COVID-19.

It's possible to have a rebound or technical rebound but given Brent is at 49 - 50 today and economic activity still sluggish because of C-virus and unlikely to recover in 1 month, then under $63 is overwhelmingly likely. Still oil is volatile and end of March has other option effects that can't rule out a possible spike, even if unlikely.

Demand is likely to remain on a low level due to coronavirus (-even if the situation in China improves, the rest of the world will be more and more affected) [3]. Supply changes are dependent on agreement between OPEC and Russia. Next meeting of the OPEC+ starts 5th March. The cartell is expected to announce supply cuts after which Russia is likely to join them [1]. However, will the cuts be enough to reach a price of $63.00 per barrel? I don't think so. There is still al lot of inventory that needs to be absorbed so the supply cuts won't already have an effect in March [2]. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec/opec-leaning-towards-larger-oil-cuts-as-virus-hits-prices-demand-sources-idUSKCN20M1MB
[2] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/27/oil-prices-could-remain-weak-in-march-and-april-sp-global-platts.html
[3] https://www.iea.org/reports/oil-market-report-february-2020
Monthly update of forecast based on monthly series using 'forecast' algorithm in R.
One month to go. Coronavirus on the way across the planet (meaning reduction of everything). 20 percent below the next bucket. Might Change in a week, but i don´t think so.
Adjusting due to continued slide and bearish outlook.
Adjusting to incorporate the passage of another day and one in which the price continues to decline. I am a couple percentage points off my monte carlo model due to coronavirus outlook.
Major economies are slowing down due to covid-19.  Brent oil is below $55 and will stay low for quite a while.
inventories building.   Many journeys being cancelled.    https://www.hellenicshippingnews.com/u-s-crude-oil-inventories-up-last-week-api/

Coronavirus. This is a high conviction forecast for me.  Currently $53.78 (https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/oil-price).  Presume oil price will fall further as virus spreads through US and Europe. (This will hit shale producers (given their financing) and high-cost producers particularly hard).  Principal risk is OPEC agreement to cut production, although given much of decline is demand-side rather than supply-side I suspect even $63 might be too high a price to get to, given the amount of oil moved to storage recently that will need to be unwound from inventory.
I'm downgrading my forecast due to the Corona virus spreading and damping the economic activity.
Citi forecasting Q1 average price of $54/barrel.
Covid19 pandemic is going to depress the global economy for a little while yet.
World economy slow down, coronavirus effect, demand down. It will stay that way for awhile.
No body wants the stuff right now, no place to put it if they bought it. This will take some time to work out.
IATA prediction on reduced demand for air travel
Slow down as things shut down and demand short term wanes.

It appears that the futures prices are falling a bit.  Moreover, the coronavirus has had a significant effect on the Chinese economy, slowing growth.  Hence, Chinese purchases of oil has fallen.  OPEC is not making further cuts despite the noise.  Russian seems to want to help Trump with re-election by keeping prices low.    If anything, I think my 80 percent estimate is low.

I am making slight adjustments towards the lower end of the spectrum because of continued concerns regarding the coronavirus which I believed would have subsided by now. Lower demand due to fears of the virus has recently dropped the price by 5%. Though it is still more than a month away, I thought that concerns with coronavirus would have lasted a week or two but now it has been more than a month and now is spreading to other countries, European ones too. The current price is around 53$ but I still have confidence depending on developing market trends that it should move up. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-markets/stocks-oil-tumble-gold-spikes-as-virus-fears-grip-markets-idUSKCN20I00F
Increased concerns surrounding global economic slowdown.

Using a Monte Carlo simulation as a prior and adjusting downward due to three factors:
1) Price has rarely neared $69 since last June.
2) Current economic environment makes spike in oil prices seem less likely than the 6% the simulation provided.
3) Reviewing futures contracts provided little indication of expectation of price improvement.

Brent is today at 58. It came down from a 60-70 level due to lower expeted activity in China due to the virus. The virus has peaked, and activity will pick up. The price mometum is up. 5 USD is a lot, but the volatility in the price is high and it droped 10 USD in 2 weeks. On the other side, it was the warmest jan, and it looks the same for feb 2020, that reduces the demand for oil. So my forecast is 38/60/2 given a weightet ave of around USD 63.
economic slowdown, and opec cant stop production in time

Revising to increase the probability of bin 1 ("Less than $63 per barrel"), given recent news: "The latest signs of infections outside the Hubei province epicentre in China spurred a selloff across financial markets" and "the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) was unlikely to add to existing supply curbs." https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/21/oil-markets-coronavirus-in-focus.html
The effects of covid19 will diminish and demand in China will slowly recover from the lowest level of $55 mid Feb.

Corona-virus fears are easing as the pandemic dwindles, Chinese work force will be in full flow by mid March, reviving demand and increasing prices, not enough time to increase above $69 but may well do towards the end of the year.

USG has reported a much smaller-than-anticipated rise in crude stocks. 
New coronavirus cases and deaths outside of China are fanning fears of global pandemic
Short-term Energy Outlook by the U.S. Energy Information Administration suggests worldwide crude oil prices will average $61 a barrel for 2020

I read another prediction based upon the futures market and agreed with it.   The futures market for Brent crude oil deliveries until the end of the year bounce around between $58 and $59.   Therefore, my prior estimate of something slightly below $63 is probably too high in the next ~40 days.

Pricing for delivery in later months through December is range-bound at $57-$58/bbl
April Pricing is $59.31/bbl
Today's pricing is $57.35/bbl - up from $54/bbl earlier in February, but far under the $70/bbl of early January. 
A reversal in pricing in six weeks to north of $69/bbl seems unlikely given anticipated global slowdown and no abatement in supply.
Pricing seems range-bound in the high 50s - and likely will persist through 31 March.
Looming supply glut, falling demand (China virus issue) and increasing downward pressure from decarbonization policies.

Coronavirus continues to impact oil markets, and even as the virus concerns ease there is still a way to go before the financial/supply chain impact is truly felt. (a lot of ships won't be heading out of Chinese ports in March!). So adjusting slightly, although I was already very bullish on <$63.
<$63: 90% → 94%
$63-69: 8% → 5%
>$69: 2% → 1%

The corona virus has changed thing substantially.  There is now a worldwide oil glut.  Opec wants to cut production but in concert with the Russians.  The Russians are silent right now but have suggested continuing the current cuts rather than making deeper cuts.  I suspect that inventories will continue to rise as reported in the media.   Nevertheless, Open will be meeting in Vienna on March 6.  We will know more then.   The price today is about $58.50.  The range since Jan 1, 2020 has been about $53.50 to about $69.00.  For the last year, the range has been about $56 to $74 if you omit the last two post-coronavirus months.  I have been trying to find a mean and a standard deviation without spending too much time on this.  (I have a job.)  I will estimate looking at charts that for the six months prior to the cronona virus the mean was probably about $61-62  and standard deviation was probably  about $5 .  Thus a range without the coronavirus would be 57 to to $67. However, the coronavirus should keep the price low for the next six weeks.   Balancing the above, $63 plus or minus $2 looks like the most likely price at the end of March.  However, I suspect less than $63 is more likely due to the inventory glut.
Demand down more than 1.7 million barrels per day, just at oil refineries. Recovery of demand, when it comes will be lightning fast.  Hence the problem of date
IEA forecast of reduced global oil demand growth
Updating for price movements over past week.

Large hit in demand from Coronavirus in China and weak growth in non-US developed economies. Possible OPEC action could raise the price, but unconventional sources mean this won't be as effective as it used to be.

Revising bin 1 down and bins 2 and 3 up given recent market movement/news: 
"Brent crude was up 89 cents or 1.6% at $57.23 per barrel. It has risen 4.4% since last Friday, its first weekly increase in six weeks...market sentiment improved as factories in China started to reopen and the government eased monetary policy in the world’s second largest economy...the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allied producers, a grouping known as OPEC+, are considering deepening production cuts" [1]. I'll be sure to keep an eye on how the COVID-19 epidemic plays out and whether OPEC agrees to further production cuts. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/14/oil-markets-crude-output-in-focus.html

Iran sanctions bypassing, venezuela potential stabilisation, ipo of aramco, OPEC desire to keep petrol based vehicles attractive and competitive vs electric threat, shale and alternative production, reflect likelihood to keep prices at present, lower, or at a marginally higher position, all of which fall under 63 a barrell (58 today). Middle East conflict would lead to price rises, reflected in higher values, as would production decrease or price increase by OPEC. EIA revised down demand levels since start of year for global forecast, albeit with increased demand forecasted. Oil futures markets optimistic. Varied pressures reflect spread of results. 69+ includes war risk. If I was to gamble on it however, I would back the $69+ chance probability vs present collective sentiment at 2%.

Barring a major conflict in the Middle East that threatens to disrupt oil supplies, and considering the increasing pressure to cut fossil fuel use due to global warming, the most likely scenario would seem to be for prices to be maintained or drop a bit.

It's at 57 today; Co19 is levelling out - the narrative is overreacting to China data, so likely to push upwards as latency kicks in. Yet, not so high as to match the 69 from September when SA got attacked.

Yesterday IETA cut demand forecasts for 1Q20. Meanwhile OPEC + Russia is responding slow to hit to demand from the Corona virus. I forecast this virus will continu to have an impact on the economy until the end of march. Adjusting forecasts...
Another day goes by in which I am delighted not to be in the oil business.  My friends who are in that business have resumed nailbiting but have not yet reverted to bedwetting.  Stay tuned.

I've updated the probabilities by moving more probability towards the lower end of the price. It is still comfortably well below 63$ hovering around 54$ as of today. I read some articles that there are demand fears for the future so it needs to be a miracle for the price to move up that much. However, I still stand by my claim that the price will be above 69$ because this is where the price goes around this time on a consistent basis. In contrast, factoring the likelihood of an event that will increase oil prices would most likely push prices higher (crisis in oil nations push prices higher as supply chains come under question). https://finance.yahoo.com/news/oil-despite-demand-fears-200000200.html

Even at low levels of confidence, the result of the current time forecast, using 2020, is less than 60USd.
However, using a three-year trend, the results vary it settles in a range between 44 and 57. According to the model, it should increase over 60USD, then dip under again by mid-march. 
Unless there is a significant event in the region (IRAN) it is likely, based on the current trend, to be under 63USD on 31 March
Reran monthly forecasting algo with updated EIA data, got slightly different result, so updating accordingly.
Continuing to move down as time passes and spot remains well into the lower range.
The Coronavirus is a black swan event.  Thus, major changes are needed in percentages.
Friday price $54, slowing China and currently calm-seeming middle east must be suppressing prices.

Hyerczyk, J. (2020). Brent Crude Oil Futures (BZ) Technical Analysis – Trade Through $56.56 Changes Momentum to Upside. FX Empire. Feb 09, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.fxempire.com/forecasts/article/brent-crude-oil-futures-bz-technical-analysis-trade-through-56-56-changes-momentum-to-upside-631797 Based on Friday’s price action and the close at $54.47, the direction of the April Brent crude oil market on Monday is likely to be determined by trader reaction to the pivot at $55.13. Side Notes
We could see a sideways to lower trade until Russia makes its decision about making larger production cuts along with OPEC and its other allies. If Russia decides not to cut production, prices could plummet.
Demand down as all those millions quarantined are not driving around. Economic activity slowing worldwide. More on bin 1.

prior rationale is basis, corrected higher price point probabilities corrected to reflect possibility of a  significant price spike

an abundance of worldwide oil supply, and potential weakened demand due to Coronavirus should keep price relatively low.  However, political unrest still remains as a risk that could create a temporary spike at any time.

Reports of cure for coronavirus have pushed price up to $54.  Chinese stimulus has also pushed up share prices. Oil inventories have built, but I think that Saudi Arabia adjusts output to set the price. It's a big ship to turn, but I am guessing they  will return it to levels pre-coronavirus by the end of March.

Bloomberg close Jan 4 =$53.80; what's a guy to, dont' fight the tape. 
Yes it will recover, but assume 1 day of shut down will take at least another day before resume normalicy.
Assume lock down lasts the 28 days of Feb and it may take 28  days to recover. It could be in the cellar for a while.
Meanwhile this takes the wind out of EU inflation.
Update based on current Forward availabilities (well below 63USD) and mostly due to current slowdown with nCoV rampant.

Prices often overshoot both ways.
The Saudis are trying to jawbone world prices - but this is not OPEC of 1973 or 1978 - and they can't afford to pull production anyway.
Their attempt at intervention means to me they probably see it falling further in the near-term.
Falling prices are breaking through near-term support levels - $55 is being tested presently.
Price recoveries seem to take 30+ days - a price recovery, given the very steady fall,would seem to take longer - pushing at the outer time frame of the question.
Odds seem slightly higher that price won't get back to $63.00+ by COB 3-31-2020 if it breaks through $54/bbl and then $50/bbl.

With the price at $54 this morning, I'm questioning everything I've thought about oil in the last few months.
There is a real chance that the price will stay below $63 through March.  The coronavirus has been mentioned in reports of a subdued oil market (WSJ report on China) - I would not have connected oil price to coronavirus.

Updating the forecast to reflect the recent downward trend in the oil price due to the Coronavirus weighing on sentiment. This is likely to way on sentiment for the near future consistent with oil futures prices and even a potential snap back in the price is unlikely to place it above $63 in the next 2 months. An oil price above $69 implies a 35% increase in the oil price in the next 2 months which appears unlikely.

A black swan came in - the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak.  It probably will have a huge significant effect on the economy of China and hence the world's demand for oil.  As the outbreak reaches the pandemic level and confirmed cases are still increasing rapidly, its effect is going to last for a while (more than 2 months).  Increasing the forecast for under $63 per barrel.

Citi sees no price revival in the near term.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-03/citi-doesn-t-see-oil-recovering-from-virus-until-fourth-quarter?utm_source=url_link

Don't believe the price will be going up anytime soon, demand dropping off and too much supply and capacity so unless there is a large change in demand or a bunch of supply comes off the market the price will be less than $63

Altering forecast for the time being, mainly based upon the following, previously unforeseen event: https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/news/oil-prices-coronavirus-slip-year-low-china-demand-falls-20-2020-2-1028868536 Also considering that the coronavirus situation could improve somewhat by 3/31/20 + possible OPEC production cuts..
Current futures have the end-of-March price well under $60. Barring a major flare-up, it's unlikely there will be a large increase in price over the next 2 months.

Bloomberg is reporting that China’s oil demand has slumped 20% since the coronavirus outbreak.
Meanwhile, oil prices are still falling:
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/03/oil-markets-coronavirus-outbreak-in-focus.html

Update of forecast obtained by applying 'forecast' function from R package of the same name to monthly time series (last close) scraped from eia.gov, with manual addition of data point for January 31, 2020, while we wait for EIA to update their series. FWIW, the algorithm selected an exponential smoothing model with a multiplicative error term, an additive trend, and no seasonality, and the point forecast for end of March is $58.75. Will update again not later than early March, possibly sooner with a weekly model if there's a lot of movement in one direction in the first couple of weeks of February.
Recent impacts of the coronavirus have impacted travel negatively, which in turn will reduce demand for fuel, which will consequently reduce demand for oil.

Narayanan, K., S. (2020). OPEC curbs, supply risks to buoy oil prices in 2020: Reuters poll. Reuters. Business News. January 31, 2020. Retrieved form
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-prices-poll/opec-curbs-supply-risks-to-buoy-oil-prices-in-2020-reuters-poll-idUSKBN1ZU1DE (Reuters) - Oil prices will remain supported near current levels this year as persistent geo-political risks and OPEC-led output curbs help offset growing supply from other producers, a Reuters poll showed on Friday. The survey of 50 economists and analysts, mainly conducted before the coronavirus outbreak, forecast benchmark Brent crude LCOc1 to average $63.48 per barrel in 2020. That compares with an average of $63.76 so far this year and last month’s forecast of $63.07.
The Corona fear is here to stay a little while massively impacting travel and things are going to be worse before they’ll get better

The outbreak of Corona virus and resulting travel restrictions leads to global demand fears for oil. Speculative investors are still long oil (~75% of open interest in oil futures) and there is a clear danger they will start to reduce as the virus keeps spreading. Adjusting forecasts to account for lower prices at the end of march.
Coronovirus has brought China to a stand still. Need for oil dipping so prices dipping. Do not know how long it will stay down. Check in a few days.

What will be the closing price for Brent crude oil on 31 March 2020?
As the coronavirus lock down spreads the need for fuel will ebb, this will take at least 2 weeks to play out, e.g. Mid-Feb at which time we could return to normal but with bloated supply for a while.
Currently low because of fear of economic impact from coronavirus outbreaks. I expect the price to rebound, but window is short.

It only took 3 day to drop down, and just as many to rise up during a panic mode market. Normalization within a week or so Slav, I. (2020).  Oil Slides On Rising Crude Inventories. Oil Price. Jan 29, 2020. Retrieved from
https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/Oil-Slides-On-Rising-Crude-Inventories.html Crude oil headed lower today, reversing a rally after the Energy Information Administration reported a build in oil inventories of 3.5 million barrels for the week to January 24.
Yet talk of a production cut extension and/or deepening has done the job and prices are trending higher for the time being. At the time of writing, Brent crude was trading at $58.75 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate was at $53.24 a barrel.

EIA anticipates a decrease in Crude prices in 2020. Inventories remain high, production may slow down (on OPEC's terms). Very good chance that the price will remain relatively steady in the mid-$60 range.

It got close to 63, too close to ignore that it might drop under 63.
I can no longer justify a raise above 69, so I'm solidly camped in the 63-69 zone.
Updating with recent price changes and current environment.

Oil has been on a steady rise in the past year. Furthermore, looking at a chart of the price over the past ten years, oil price tends to be higher during March in relation to past months. As it gets warmer, people will go out more often, and drive more often increasing demand for oil. Libya tensions bump up Brent quotes.

Brent oil prices have gradually increased since October 2019 following heightened geopolitical risk in the Middle East; specifically, attacks on Saudi oil infrastructure, increased conflict risk between the U.S. and Iran, in addition to heightened domestic sociopolitical risks in Iraq. Most recently, in the Mediterranean, France, Germany, Italy, Greece, Cyprus, Turkey and Russia contend over the formation of a new government in Libya - as well as its hydrocarbon riches. Libya's National Oil Corporation (NOC) shut down two oilfields after forces loyal to Haftar closed a pipeline, raising Brent prices to $65.22 on 20 Jan 2020.  However, despite this, upticks in crude have not held, nor had as adverse impact that many predicted. One reason for this is due to subdued demand amidst the US-China trade war. Another reason is due to oversupply in the oil market - one expected to last for the first half of 2020. This is due to continued growth by US shale producers. Furthermore, OECD countries' oil inventories are 9 million barrels above the five-year average - with plenty other strategic stockpiles to call upon in the event of an outage.  Thus, oil prices are most likely to stay in the $63-69 per barrel range - accounting for persistent geopolitical tensions in the region despite the deescalation in tensions between the US and Iran. Scenarios where oil trades higher include further supply cuts by OPEC states and Russia (OPEC+) and/or a marked increase in tensions in Iraq. Scenarios where oil trades lower would see an overall deescalation in Middle East tensions; specifically, Iraq, which is an at-risk major global producer. Moreover, in the run-up of the 2020 US elections, President Trump will opt for policies that favour lower oil prices.
Due to vigorous escalation in the middle east

However, there remain risks which could provoke upward pressure: geopolitical tension leading to potential supply shocks remains elevated post the Iran-US incidents; the Fed’s interest rate cuts and trade deal progress could improve demand.

It is well-known that oil prices are sensitive to the global economy and geopolitical events, especially in the volatile Middle East.  Economic conditions are, in general, slow evolving while political events are sporadic and sudden.  The latter introduce jolts to the system and hence affect the oil prices.  As the political situation stabilizes, oil prices tend to go back to their underlying pre-jolt values.  (This is my view anyway.) Lets look at the oil prices in the last year.  There is a sharp drop in the oil price in early June 2019 due to worries about the global economy (1).  It hovers around $63 for the rest of the year (2).  Many events happened in the Middle East during this period: attack and seizure of oil tankers, attack of the Saudi’s oil production facilities, downing of US and Iranian drones, and the recent killing of an Iranian General and Iranian missile attack on military bases in Iraq.  Despite spiking after these events, the oil prices appear to drop back to a level perceivably sustainable by the economic condition (hovering around $63). From June 3, 2019 till now, the average Brent oil is $62.6 with a standard deviation of $2.7.  56% of the daily close prices are <$63, 43% between $63 and $69 and 1% >$69.  I consider this as the baseline case for recent oil prices perturbed by political events. There is no way to tell when the current political situation will stabilize.  Another way to examine the situation is to analyze the prices from Nov 1, 2019 to now and use the analysis to forecast the oil price two and half month in the future (March 31, 2020) (Nov 1 is two and half month in the past).  In this period, the average price is $64.4 with a standard deviation of $2.2.  31% of the daily close prices are <$63, 69% between $63 and $69 and 0% >$69. Right now, I am choosing the latter scenario for my forecast.  If the situation stabilizes soon in the near future, I might switch back to the first scenario.  (1)  https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/04/oil-markets-us-crude-stockpiles-in-focus.html
(2)  https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/historical-prices/oil-price/usd/16.12.2018_16.1.2020?type=brent

Another area/relationship I have been reviewing in the oil markets this week is how the value of the dollar affects oil prices. Oil (even Brent) is priced in dollars so a weakening dollar increases prices because it takes more of a less valuable currency to buy one unit of the commodity.  Lately, a big portion of the dollars fluctuations has had to do with Federal Reserve policy expectations and demand for Treasurys, among other things (https://www.thebalance.com/value-of-us-dollar-3306268). A recently improving global outlook, decline in trade risk, and solid data from the US consumer have encouraged the Fed to maintain their path holding rates constant. While I do not think these conditions will last, my base case (as I’ve shared in other forecasts) is for a strong Q1 followed by increasing uncertainty as the risks from 2019 that were “kicked down the road” in Q4 materialize. At least in the near-term, the markets seem to have similar view of Fed action (https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html).  So what does this mean for oil prices? A steady Fed translates to a flat or strengthening dollar (all else equal) which will put downward pressure on oils prices. That combined with reduced geo-political tensions in recent weeks makes me think oil prices will return to their range from the past few months.

The price of Brent Crude is pretty volatile.  Prices since 2009 seem to indicate a break in the trend around 2015 (probably when US fracking began to seriously increase production).   It would seem fair to suggest a break in the series data around the beginning of 2015.   Since 2015, mean price is $57.01 with 95% of data within $32.95 to $81.07, 68% of data within bracket $44.98 to $69.04.   Using five year data and assuming a normal distribution this would suggest:  Price < $63 - probability 64%
 $63 < Price < $69 - probability of 20%
Price > $69  - probability of 16% The one year average is $64.25 with 95% of data within bracket $55.52 to $72.99, 68% of data within bracket $59.89 to $68.62.  Using one year data and assuming a normal distribution this would suggest:  Price < $63 - probability 39%
 $63 < Price < $69 - probability of 47%
Price > $69  - probability of 14% The price of $69.26 on 26th December 2019 is toward the upper end of the distribution.   The biggest increase in price over three months in 2019 was January to March from around $54 to $66 (+$12).  The biggest drop was from May to August from $74 to $55 (-$19).   From the current price toward the top of the distribution there will likely be a fall over the next three months.  A drop of over $6 is highly plausible.   The trend over both 1 and 5 years is negative.  Without a change to the fundamentals of the market, there is little reason to assume a shift in the distribution of prices since 2015.  (The US and Iran have not gone to war at the time of writing).  I will therefore predict in line with five year data.  Data source: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DCOILBRENTEU#0 . Calculations my own.

The price is primarily dependent upon the geopolitical situation, as this has effects on both supply and demand. This question is therefore asking for a forecast of the geopolitical situation in 3 months' time, in an extremely unstable part of the world.  However, it is hard to see the price per barrel falling below $63, as this would require a huge increase in production, assuming demand doesn't plummet in the next three months. This is intuitively unlikely; the more likely scenario is a fall in production due to eg war between the US and Iran, terrorism, economic sanctions etc. The price is currently around $69 a barrel, and I have no real reason to expect it to be higher or lower in 3 months' time.

Why Oil Stocks’ Response to Latest Mideast Trouble Is Different This Time Salzman (2020) Jan. 3, stated that: There was no question that oil prices would rally after the United States assassinated top Iranian military commander Qassem Soleimani on Thursday night. Any conflict in the Middle East is bound to shock oil markets higher, because it threatens to destabilize the center of the global oil market. But the size of the rally and its impact on particular stocks are unique to this conflict and the recent history of oil price movements. Brent crude futures rose 3.8% to $68.84 a barrel in Friday morning trading, and futures on West Texas Intermediate, or WTI, the market benchmark in the U.S., gained 3.7% to $63.44. Recent history is affecting Friday’s move. The latest similar oil spike occurred on Sept. 16, the first trading day after a series of attacks on Saudi Arabian oil infrastructure. Brent jumped 20% after the attacks to $71.95, before slipping back below $70. Within two weeks, oil prices had retraced all of their gains, and the stocks that had followed the commodity higher had plunged. That has left traders a little wary of chasing a rally that is based on geopolitical considerations that are difficult to predict. “We expect a near term increase in commodity prices to favor U.S. E&Ps, particularly high beta name where there is also a fair amount of short interest as well,” wrote RBC Capital Markets analyst Scott Hanold in a note on Friday. “However, investors could be a bit more gun shy given how quickly equities retraced following the Saudi attack in September” (Para. 1-5). *
Reference
* Salzman, A. (2020). Why Oil Stocks’ Response to Latest Mideast Trouble Is Different This Time. Barron’s. Energy. Jan. 3, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.barrons.com/articles/oil-stocks-iran-attack-saudi-crude-iraq-51578068294

I looked up three year trends on oil prices, and observed that there was a trend of a dip in March.  This makes sense, as gas prices will drop with a higher temperature.  Similarly, crude oil prices will rise as the demand for electricity to cool buildings rises in the heat of summer.  I also observed a trend in the data since 2015, wherin the price slowly rose afterwards.  OLPEC may be dysfunctional, but it still raises crude oil prices.  Meanwhile, if I am not mistaken, oil reserves in Saudi Arabia run dry, and thus their market share drops.  In addition, demand for crude oil is rising, as it has been since it was first used.  This shows no likelihood of stopping without dramatic change.
Slowing shale production in 2020 plus OPEC+ actions to curb productiont in order to support oil prices

Starting off with a fairly general forecast mainly based upon some current analysis (links) -- which seems more or less split between generally stable oil prices (in 2020) and (certain developments adding) some moderate upward pressure. 
Will further research and adjust as necessary in the weeks ahead. https://www.cnbc.com/2019/10/23/oil-prices-goldman-sachs-says-brent-futures-are-going-nowhere-in-2020.html https://www.marketwatch.com/story/extreme-weather-seen-impacting-oil-prices-in-2020-as-well-as-geopolitics-2019-12-11 https://finance.yahoo.com/news/crude-oil-outlook-2020-3-193321624.html https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/JP-Morgan-Raises-2020-Oil-Price-Outlook.html https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/prices.php

Brent crude is the global benchmark for oil supplies. It is most sensitive to the global economic outlook (demand), OPEC+ and other (primarily US shale producers) supply, and geo-political risks (https://www.eia.gov/finance/markets/crudeoil/). Let's start with some forecasts:
- EIA suggests $59 a barrel for Brent in March (https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/data/browser/#/?v=8&f=M&s=0&start=201501&end=202012&ctype=linechart&maptype=0&linechart=BREPUUS~&map=)
- WSJ survey suggests a range of $52 - 64 (with a similar midpoint as EIA) (https://www.wsj.com/graphics/econsurvey/) On the demand front, consensus estimates from major banks and asset managers is for an increase in global GDP growth is 2020 (https://www.wsj.com/graphics/econsurvey/). Major themes are a reduction in trade uncertainty, global CB easing, strong consumer, etc. This increase would support higher demand and higher prices. My view is for a short-term cyclical re-firming over the next few months. However, the realities of the global trade impasse and limited CB effectiveness will ultimately bring expectations down. On the supply side, OPEC+ recently agreed to cut production by an additional 500k barrels starting in 2020 (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec/opec-sees-small-2020-oil-deficit-even-before-latest-supply-cut-idUSKBN1YF1LK) and US shale producers are focusing on paying down debts and improving cash flows (https://www.wsj.com/articles/frackers-prepare-to-pull-back-exacerbating-a-slowdown-in-u-s-oil-growth-11573478550).  To me, one of the most interesting dynamics in oil markets is the cap that shale producers have put of global oil prices. This cap keeps the range on WTI between $40-60 a barrel (which typically trades at a $6-7 discount to Brent - based on a simple regression of WTI to Brent using EIA data). The discount has a lot to do with higher transport and refining costs for WTI. Getting back to the range, however, the Fed Bank of Dallas (https://www.dallasfed.org/research/economics/2019/0521) suggests that long-dated futures are a good proxy for this breakeven based on the marginal cost of supply. That theory and futures contract data from the CME Group (https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/energy/crude-oil/brent-crude-oil.html) suggest that it will be difficult for prices to rise much above $60. I don't have too much on the geo-political front - obviously tail risks remain. However, if September taught me anything, it is that uncertainty in the Middle East doesn't impact prices like it used to. Short of a hot war, I don't think there will be much price action. Bringing it back together, here is a brief summary:
	- increasing prices over the next few months
		- diminished trade uncertainty drives improving global outlook through Feb
		- US producers rig cuts and OPEC+ cuts limit global supply
		- weaker dollar as the Fed holds steady on rates
	- decline later in March and February
		- actual text of US China trade deal disappoints relative to expectations
		- UK trade deal uncertainty increases after vote to leave 
		- rising prices improve prospects for shale producers and more supply pulling prices down
	- Risks:
		- consensus economic outlook (~2% GDP growth) is correct supporting higher prices
		- Trade deals meet expectations
		- US production stays low as producers pay off debts and focus on positive cash flow
		- Scope - my outlook could be right, but it doesn't materialize until later in the year Ultimately, I believe lower prices are the most likely outcome but the scope of this question limits my willingness to bet. Over the time-frame, I see plenty of risks on the upside. That being said, most of the upside risks are expectations-based (and I anticipate the market is a little too bullish at the moment).

Basically compute changes in oil prices and then take draws on those get estimates of prices going forward. Dec 20 Brent is at $66 before cuts have much impact.
Lots of good rationale from others, but it appears that OPEC is determined to cut production and raise prices off their sub-$60 nadir. The question is how much is enough? Since this is throttle to supply, prices should not get too much over $75.

Random walk model: 36, 19, 45 Several bullish factors are present: fiscal stimuli in China and India, easing of US-China trade tensions, and a recently reaffirmed commitment to cut supply by OPEC + Russia. On the bearish side is a reversal in the fortunes of the US economy. So far the consumer side of the economy has been strong with the recent unemployment data reaching a new low but there are questions as to just how low unemployment can go (akin to squeezing the last bit of toothpaste out of the tube). If the labor market were to start showing any signs of reversal it would sap sentiment in financial markets and by extension oil.
